page.title: 02HOLMESFIELD'S LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: The earliest surviving remains in the area are the high mounds or knowles built by Neolithic folk and around which hut circles were built. Later the Romans built Rumbling Street, which skirts the Southern boundary of our area,from the lead mining areas of the Peak District to Chesterfield. The Angles used the Neolithic 'mounds'to build their 'cruck' Halls or 'aulas' and they also built the mill near the ford ,the settlement now called Millthorpe . The conquering Normans built a Motte and Bailey castle from which the moat and castle mill is still visible.Lead smelting on windy Bole hills to the west of the area brought wealth to Holmesfield families in the 1500's and the aulas were developed into fine Tudor halls. Ancient crosses still mark the original pack horse trails.
